Revised IRM to make editorial changes to update and provide an overview of the process utilized by the Appeals Quality Measurement System (AQMS).
IRM 8.1.7.4.8 - Removed language discussing measuring actions taken by Tax Specialists
IRM 8.1.7 dated April 16, 2013 is superseded.

) The mission of the IRS Independent Office of Appeals (Appeals) is to federal tax controversies without litigation on a basis which is fair and to both the Government and the taxpayer, promotes a consistent application and interpretation of, and voluntary compliance with, the federal tax laws, enhances public conÔ¨Ådence in the integrity and efficiency of the IRS. accomplishes its mission by considering protested and Tax Court cases and negotiating settlements in a manner which ensures Appeals employees act accord with the Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR) in every interaction with taxpayers. See IRM
, Accomplishing the Appeals Mission. (
) The requirement for an organizational measure of quality for the IRS was tablished as part of the Restructuring and Reform Act of
(RRA
CFR
(b), Quality Measures. (
CFR

(b) states that quality measures focus on whether IRS ‚Ä¢ Devoted an appropriate amount of time to a matter ‚Ä¢ Properly analyzed the facts of the situation ‚Ä¢ Complied with statutory, regulatory and IRS procedures ‚Ä¢ Took timely actions ‚Ä¢ Provided adequate notiÔ¨Åcation and made required contacts with taxpayers (

) The Director, Case and Operations Support (C&OS) has the executive sibility for designing, developing, delivering, and monitoring short and long- range tax administration policies, programs, strategies, and objectives for Appeals organization. (

) The Director, Policy, Planning, Quality and Analysis is responsible for technical and procedural guidance to Appeals employees and establishing maintaining policies and standard procedures for Appeals work streams. (
) The Policy Analyst shown on the Product Catalog page as the originator is assigned author of this IRM. (

) AQMS data can be generated down to the Area level. There are three available through ACDS for AQMS results. ‚Ä¢ Summary Statistics Report - This report provides the percentage by AQMS Standard and overall AQMS score. ‚Ä¢ Standards Success Rate Report - This report provides individual tics for the Attributes and Reason Codes of each AQMS Standard. ) The mission of the IRS Independent Office of Appeals (Appeals) is to resolve federal tax controversies without litigation on a basis which is fair and to both the Government and the taxpayer, promotes a consistent application and interpretation of, and voluntary compliance with, the federal tax laws, and enhances public conÔ¨Ådence in the integrity and efficiency of the IRS. Appeals accomplishes its mission by considering protested and Tax Court cases and negotiating settlements in a manner which ensures Appeals employees act in accord with the Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR) in every interaction with taxpayers. See IRM
, Accomplishing the Appeals Mission. (

(RRA

) Appeals Quality Measurement System Webpage (
) The Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR) lists rights that already existed in the tax code, putting them in simple language and grouping them into
fundamental rights. Employees are responsible for being familiar with and acting in accord with taxpayer rights. See IRC
), Execution of Duties in Accord with Taxpayer Rights. For additional information about the TBOR, see https://www. irs.gov/taxpayer-bill-of-rights. (

) Balanced Measures of Performance is one of the Ô¨Åve levels of change in the IRS Modernization effort. The goals of Balanced Measures are to provide mation on organizational performance and to highlight areas for performance improvement.
Balanced Measures of Performance is one of the Ô¨Åve levels of change in the IRS Modernization effort. The goals of Balanced Measures are to provide infor
mation on organizational performance and to highlight areas for performance improvement.
Purpose and Guidelines
page (

) Key output measures are used to assess organizational performance. Each functional unit, including Appeals, has a customized set of output measures within the Balanced Measures framework. AQMS: ‚Ä¢ Is the quality measure of the Business Results component of Appeals Balanced Measures. ‚Ä¢ Does not establish policy. ‚Ä¢ Was developed to provide statistically valid data on case quality for Appeals. (
) The Taxpayer First Act (TFA) enacted July

, clariÔ¨Åed the Appeals nization as the IRS Independent Office of Appeals and established speciÔ¨Åc goals to modernize the IRS and enhance the taxpayer experience. The Act requires the IRS to develop a thorough strategy for improving customer service. AQMS provides information to measure how well Appeals communi- cates with its customers, resolves cases, and treats its customers. (

) AQMS results are used to assess the performance of Appeals as an tion. AQMS results are not, under any circumstances, used to measure the Use of AQMS individual performance of Appeals employees. AQMS is designed and as a useful tool for executive and top level managers to use in determining strengths and weaknesses of the quality of the Appeals process. (
) Any feedback or other work products generated from AQMS are not used as substitute for case reviews, case Ô¨Åle reviews, on the job visits and workload reviews. (
) Closed cases are selected for AQMS review by a random sampling process that provides a statistically valid measurement with
% conÔ¨Ådence level Cases for or minus
% error rate) to the Area level for an annual period. The case sampling system is designed to ensure a representative number of cases selected from each Appeals Area. (
) The criteria used in selecting the representative case samples are Collection (Examples: CDP, TFRP, OIC, etc.) or Non-Collection (Examples: Income tax, Employment tax, PENAP, etc.) types. (
) In addition to randomly selected cases, Closed Case Reviews may be conducted on certain types of cases at the request of Appeals Executive agement. (
) AQMSSELECT is the indicator automatically set when the case is selected AQMS review based on programmed criteria. (

) When APS closes a case selected for AQMS review, ACDS generates an automated and completed AQMS Coversheet. APS will print and attach the coversheet to the case Ô¨Åle. Upon closing the case, APS ensures documents identiÔ¨Åed on the form are included in the case Ô¨Åle. APS then forwards the selected closed case to the appropriate AQMS reviewer/office as identiÔ¨Åed the form. APS closing procedures for AQMS designated cases can be found IRM
, Account and Processing Support Manual, Closing Procedures. (

) The AQMS rating system provides an objective, consistent, and equitable scoring system for selected cases and emphasizes Standards identiÔ¨Åed as System factors for ensuring an acceptable quality Appeals process. (

When APS closes a case selected for AQMS review, ACDS generates an automated and completed AQMS Coversheet. APS will print and attach the coversheet to the case Ô¨Åle. Upon closing the case, APS ensures documents identiÔ¨Åed on the form are included in the case Ô¨Åle. Appeals (
) The AQMS rating system consists of eight key Standards for Appeals cases and seven key Standards for Collection Appeals cases. (
) Quality Standards provide objective criteria upon which case quality is evaluated. Each one provides concise statements of Appeals‚Äô expectations quality work product. Reason (
) Each Quality Standard contains one or more Attributes that deÔ¨Åne the uisite of a quality case and reÔ¨Çect Appeals‚Äô goals. (
) Some Attributes have Reason Codes. Reason Codes are speciÔ¨Åc actions or tasks that are contrary to Appeals‚Äô goals. (

) Each Attribute is worded as a question. When rating aspects of cases to an Attribute, the AQMS reviewer assigns an answer of MET, NOT MET, and NOT APPLICABLE to each applicable Attribute. For an Attribute with Codes, the rating of the Attribute is determined based on whether any of Reason Codes for the Attribute are selected. (
) Reason Codes provide detailed information used for analytical purposes. Reason Codes are used as a management tool to identify the cause(s) of missed Attribute. (

) Narrative comments are required for some Reason Codes and Attributes. A narrative comment is a brief summary of the AQMS reviewer‚Äôs about a given Attribute or Reason Code. They are used to explain the Attributes are rated NOT MET and to further explain why a Reason Code selected. They are also used to provide favorable comments. (
) The rating assigned to an Attribute by the AQMS reviewer is a component the overall score of the related Standard. (
) The AQMS Review Check Sheet is a form outlining the Quality Standards, tributes, and Reason Codes. AQMS reviewers use the check sheet to Check systematically score each case. See IRM
and IRM
) The check sheet outlines the criteria for rating each Standard and includes comment section for each Standard, Attribute, and Reason Code. (

) When completing the check sheet, AQMS reviewers take into account the niÔ¨Åcance of both positive and negative aspects of the case Ô¨Åle and their respective impact on the Standards, Attributes, and/or Reason Codes. (

) For many of the Attributes or Reason Codes, AQMS reviewers are required use the comment section to discuss NOT MET ratings on any Attribute or Reason Codes and they are asked to share favorable comments regarding Standards and Attributes. AQMS reviewers must ensure their comments meaningful, clear and easily understood. (
) The check sheet is updated annually. (
) To provide statistically valid data on case quality for Appeals, it is important have consistency among the reviewers in evaluating cases and to have a procedure in place to evaluate consistency.
The AQMS rating system consists of eight key Standards for Non-Collection Appeals cases and seven key Standards for Collection Appeals cases.

check sheet outlines the criteria for rating each Standard and includes a section for each Standard, Attribute, and Reason Code.
Purpose and Guidelines
) Consistency checks are performed by having reviewers independently the same case and comparing the consistency of the ratings for each and the selection of Reason Codes. (
) Group meetings are held by the AQMS reviewers to discuss speciÔ¨Åc the consistency reviews and methods to ensure consistency in the review cases. (

) Each year AQMS issues a report containing the statistical Ô¨Åndings for Non- Collection case reviews and for Collection case reviews. Recommendations Annual Report each Appeals Organizational Function are included in the report. The Desk Report identiÔ¨Åes recommendations for improvement and areas in which Appeals should focus. (

) The AQMS Reviewer‚Äôs Desk Guide should be used when interpreting or analyzing the AQMS reports. The AQMS Reviewer‚Äôs Desk Guide is to provide review and rating guidance to AQMS reviewers. The AQMS er‚Äôs Desk Guides, check sheets, and the AQMS Annual Reports are posted the AQMS website. (
) The scores for all applicable Standards are totaled to determine the case score. The maximum case score is
points. Scoring System (

) The scoring system provides equal ratings for each applicable Standard. applicable Standard earns points (up to a maximum per Standard) based the number of Attributes within the Standard determined to be rated MET or NOT MET. (

) The score for the Standard is a percentage for the Standard based on the number of Attributes rated MET divided by the number of applicable (the total MET and NOT MET Attributes) for the Standard. (
) Attributes rated as NOT APPLICABLE are not counted. (

) The AQMS reviewer‚Äôs check sheet is a form outlining the Quality Attributes, and Reason Codes. AQMS reviewers use the check sheet to Review Check tematically score each case. The check sheet outlines the criteria for rating for Non-Collection each Standard and includes a comment section for each Standard, and Reason Code. (

measures whether Appeals: ‚Ä¢ Timely communicated with the taxpayers in an appropriate, Service and manner; Rights ‚Ä¢ Addressed the taxpayers‚Äô needs; and
) ‚Ä¢ Respected the taxpayers‚Äô rights. Cases (

) The IRS is committed to providing taxpayers with customer service that tates easier interactions with the IRS, provides assistance with taxpayers‚Äô needs as necessary, and delivers professional treatment. This requires that Appeals keep taxpayers appropriately informed throughout the Appeals process and give them sufficient time to present their case.

Appeals (
) Respecting taxpayers‚Äô rights involves both advising them of their rights observing those rights in Appeals‚Äô actions. Appeals must always keep the taxpayers‚Äô rights as the top priority. (
) For Standard

to be rated at the maximum allowable score, the following actions must be taken on the case: a. Advise taxpayers of their rights, b. Explain the Appeals process, c. Follow privacy, disclosure and ex parte rules, and d. Keep the taxpayer and/or representative informed throughout the process. (
) To keep the taxpayer and/or representative informed about the status of case, contact should be initiated timely and continue throughout the process. (

measures whether the Appeals settlement is supported by a reasoned analysis of facts and law. Issues referred to Appeals are Decision controversial and rest upon judgment and opinion on which reasonable
) may hold divergent views. Resolving these issues requires consideration Cases relevant facts and law. (
) The AQMS reviewer will not substitute personal preference for the the Appeals Technical Employee (ATE) when the decision is fairly facts and applicable law. (

is rated at the maximum allowable score when the following occurs: a. The settlement is consistent with the legal authority, b. Relevant facts support the decision, and c. Settlement/decision reÔ¨Çects relevant interpretation of the law, facts litigating hazards as applied to the case. (
